Alternative is “сэзъяны” with the same NOM_INS pattern. The difference between the two structures is not fully clear. According to some sources “сэзъяны” is actually more suitable here, as is must be used in contexts where the object moved is for example a flag or the like, whereas “шонаны” is more appropriate in contexts like “waved his hand”. However, Ksenia’s “students” all preferred “шонаны”.

NV. This is the default version for both Sveta and the students. The Y component is a full-fledged NP, cf. “Ки-ы тынад духи-ед зын” [рука-POSS.1SG 2SG.GEN духи-POSS.2SG запах], where Y has its own possessor. This pattern does not involve any overt marking at all. Apart from this, one can say зын лыктэ «the smell is going», зын потэ «the smell emanates, stinks », but there is no neutral verb.
Ksenia: This is Sveta’s choice, the students prefer the TR pattern.

back_translation_en: ‘This belt goes well with my dress.’

This option was preferred by 4 out of 7 respondents. Others used the TR pattern with the same verb.
Ksenia: Sveta did not provide any translation, this option was suggested by the majority of the students.
CV

Alternative is the transitive construction, but it is mainly used in constructions like “understand a question” etc., cf. “Петя та юан-эз вала” [PN.NOM this question-ACC understand.PRS.3SG] ‘Petja understands this question.’ Students also used the transitive construction with “language”. This pattern here is rather like “understand in French”. The same marker is also used in phrases like “according to me”, “in a new way”, etc., but it can also be attached to the noun phrase “French language”, cf. француз кыл сямен (“in French language”), which is an argument for treating this as a regular argument-encoding marker.
Students also suggested some other verbs, also with this pattern.

Even with pronouns, the Y argument is in the nominative, not accusative, cf. “Мон ч:аша понна сю манет тыр-и, со сомында ик сыл-э вал” [1SG cup for 100 ruble pay-PST.3SG. it(=cup) so_much AFF cost-PRS.3SG AUX.PST] "I paid 100 rbles for the cup. It was not worth it = It did not cost it. However, the actual usage pattern with various NP-types in the Y position is not clear. But Sveta insists that this is NOM and NOM (not ACC).
Alternative is the TR pattern, favored by the students, but both Sveta and the dictionary claim that this would imply that the shor was successful.

comms: Arguably, the NP in the genitive is a clause-level dependent.
comms_internal: The same verb as in 14 (different pattern). This constructions is problematic. First of all, Sveta used a completely different construction with “кулэ” and DAT_NOM. Second, the structure with “пот-э” was unanimouly suggested by the students, but maybe this is not “proper Udmurt”. Interstingly, there is no possessive marker on the “phone”, so that the genitive seems to be indeed external. However, it is not entirely clear whether the Y argument triggers any agreement on the verb here, as most of the time, this patter is used with dependent clauses. Overall, the classification of this patter as GEN_NOM is tentative.
